finding: Google's code review hierarchy defines three distinct roles: Peer Reviewer (correctness/comprehension via LGTM), Code Owner (domain approval via codebase location), and Readability Reviewer (certification-based authority). Ownership is NOT tied to seniority but to domain expertise and code location.
source: Google Engineering Practices; Aviator CODEOWNERS Guide
relevance: Addresses C1 by providing reviewer role taxonomy applicable to YOLO agents. Scout, Critic, Debugger, Security, Tester each have distinct approval authorities.

finding: CODEOWNERS-style file-based assignment is industry standard. Maps file patterns to required reviewers, ensuring domain experts always review changes in their area.
source: Aviator CODEOWNERS Guide; Swarmia Code Review Guide
relevance: YOLO needs formalized agent-to-artifact ownership mapping. Create CODEOWNERS-style matrix showing which agents own which artifact types.

finding: Quality gates are milestone checkpoints requiring predefined criteria before phase progression. Gates operate at two levels: automated (policy enforcement) and manual (approval gates with human sign-off).
source: testrigor.com; InfoQ Pipeline Quality Gates; TechTarget
relevance: Addresses C5 by defining quality criteria for Architect→Lead handoff. Needs explicit gates: architecture completeness, cross-phase dependency mapping, security considerations.

finding: Design handoff completeness checklist: final specs for all states, production-ready assets, interactive prototypes, copy deck. Handoff QA automation flags risky suggestions for human review.
source: Fast.io Design Handoff Best Practices 2025; Unified Image Tools AI Design Handoff QA 2025
relevance: Template for C5: Architect→Lead handoff should specify what artifacts constitute 'complete': waves decomposed, dependencies mapped, must_haves testable.

finding: Review cycles metric: 1-2 cycles optimal, 3+ indicates process friction. Smaller PRs resolve in fewer cycles. Hard limits create perverse incentives. Metric should be context-aware.
source: Software.com Engineering Metrics; LinearB 2025 Benchmarks; Swarmia
relevance: Confirms YOLO's 2-cycle max is industry-aligned. Add metric tracking and escalation triggers for Phase 4 continuous QA.

finding: Agile change management: RFC formalization for scope changes. Classify as Minor (routine) or Major (design impact). Minor auto-approves after cycle 1 if nits only. Major escalates if cycle 2 has findings.
source: Medium: Code Review as Team Process; PCI Security Standards RFC
relevance: Formalizes C7's revision cycles: classify Dev changes as Minor/Major, different escalation paths for each.

finding: Senior engineer role in Agile: provides guidance, catches high-level issues, not override authority. Treats Dev as collaborator. Leadership guides process quality but doesn't bypass author agency.
source: Agile Modeling: Architecture Owner Role; Xebia Architects in Scrum
relevance: Senior↔Dev cycles should be collaborative refinement, not gatekeeping. Send review changes as suggestions, Dev retains decision power within spec.

finding: Distributed code ownership: ownership = approval rights + read responsibility + escalation duty when unsure. Prevents rubber-stamp approvals.
source: Google Code Review; Swarmia Knowledge Sharing
relevance: When defining agent ownership, include responsibility definition (must analyze, must document reasoning, must escalate conflicts).

finding: Phase gate process (stage-gate model): gate = decision point. Three decision paths: Go (proceed), Recycle (rework + resubmit), Kill (defer to future phase).
source: Smartsheet Phase Gate Process; Stage-Gate International
relevance: Structured gate model for C5's Architect→Lead handoff: Entry criteria, Gate review, Exit decision (Go/Recycle/Kill).

finding: Continuous QA integration (2025): quality gates include DORA metrics. QA gates are automated, not manual approval stages. Gates auto-block non-emergency changes during incidents.
source: DevOps Training Institute CI/CD Quality Gates 2025
relevance: Phase 3 should define metrics that gate Phase 4: review cycle count, test coverage, security findings. Set SLOs so Phase 4 knows success criteria.
